Couple years ago I was fishing alone in northern Canada, I was on the lake and saw another dude fishing on shore yelling about something. Looked thru my binoculars and saw foxes were attacking him. There were about 20 foxes. The foxes won and ripped thru his clothes and had a feast. I quietly rowed over so as not to scare the foxes with my outboard motor and so I could get a better look. After an hour there was nothing left but his bones. Foxes ate him all up. I didn't want rangers to find the scene and kill the foxes, so I went on shore and cleaned up the 'crime scene'. Built a fire to burn the clothes, took all his supplies into my boat, washed the blood away with buckets of water from the lake, and collected all his bones in buckets. I dropped the bones in the middle of the lake where they'd never be found. Once in a while I google his name that I got from his wallet but thankfully nothing new ever comes up besides the initial missing report.

cont. from: >>4363941

This thread is dedicated to all animals of the reptilia and amphibia classes. Topics include, but are not limited to: geckos, snakes of all kinds, frogs, salamanders, newts, turtles, tortoises, and much more. Before asking a question, do a search on the internet to see if it has been answered
Classifieds for finding breeders and products:
>morphmarket.com
>kingsnake.com
>faunaclassifieds.com
>reptilescanada.com (Canadian breeders)
>caudata.org
Most forums will have a "for sale" section on them, so look for that, especially if you have a specific herp you want. Craigslist can also be a good source for cheap aquariums, and make sure to check for any reptile expos that occur in your area.

When asking a question, make sure to include these details:
>Type and size of animal
>Enclosure dimensions
>Humidity and temperature
>Type of substrate
>The decor you use
>How often you feed
>The type of food you use
>If your animal is wild caught or captive bred
>How often you handle
>Who you bought the animal from

Other Helpful Resources
www.blackjungleterrariumsupply.com
www.joshsfrogs.com
http://www.reptilesmagazine.com
http://www.anapsid.org
http://www.hylid.clara.co.uk/caer.htm
https://www.americanmadeexotics.com/breeding-ball-pythons-article.html
http://blogs.thatpetplace.com/thatreptileblog/

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4376976
I'm pretty much in the same spot you are (looking to acquire a leopard gecko in the near future), and So I've considered the same stuff.
>roaches
Turns out adult dubias are too big for leopard geckos, so you MIGHT be able to feed those off to your chickens, but it may also be uneconomical to cultivate those.
>mealworms
piss easy to cultivate, and require very little in the way of maintenance (put bugs in oatmeal, add cruciferous vegetable scraps for moisture, wait, get bugs, replace oatmeal and cruiferous vegetables as needed) so I'd recommend doing that regardless of your gecko-getting status just for your chickens. fresh is better than dried, and you can probably also feed off the adult beetles to chickens/your gecko too
>superworms/darkling beetles
same as mealworms, just sequester some of the larvae in a little film canisters/similar sized container with some vents in it so they pupate.
>wax worms/black soldier fly larvae/hornworms
cheap as chips and and a sometimes food over your staple bugs - go somewhere like dubia.com or rainbow mealworms, you'll see it's like 5-10 bucks for something you'll do once a month. BSF larvae are also apparently GREAT for chickens as they're super high in calcium, but are a little harder to culture, so while it's challenging it may be worth it just to check that out anyway.
>crickets
fuck crickets.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4377037
that's what I did, but think of it like this - dubia colonies take a few months to get going if you're starting with a handful of nymphs. Leos take a few months to get big enough to eat all but the full grown adult roaches. So what I'd do is buy a couple dozen dubia nymphs when you get the leo and get the dubias set up in a tub with some egg crate in a warm spot. By the time they're reproducing your gecko will be ready to eat them.
I guess it's not economical in that I probably get more roach deaths due to culling and natural causes than actually get fed to the gecko. But even just accounting for the cost of gasoline to get feeders they've more than paid for themselves.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4378125
Just set up a pig blanket for those 50 degree nighttime dips during the summer. Anything big you'd have to take inside for prolonged cold temps anyway. You could probably make a rock iguana work if you give it a chance to have a humid cave or burrow and bring it inside any time temps threaten to go south of 60. They're more easy going than an agrus, more tolerant of low humidity than you'd expect, and they live for 30+ years with good care. The Cuban I've got is one of the only lizards I've ever owned that will sometimes march over to me and ignore food in favor of scratches. But they do take a while, both to get that friendly and grow to the size you seem to be looking for. And I've heard some people say that theirs have randomly gotten mean after 3 years of being chill, but I've had mine for 8 now and she's only gotten nicer with age so your milage may vary.
Gonna second the other guys recommending a sulcata, there's tons of abandoned footstool sized fellas wasting away in animal rescues who'd kill for a nice Arizona backyard to take over [spoiler]and destroy[/spoiler]. But again, you'd need a heated shed for cooler temps.

>>4379486
A lot of it is social conditioning. Children observe adults freaking out about snakes or thinking toads are slimy and gross, and watch characters in media with phobias of them and learn the behavior, and when they encounter these animals and act scared it's reinforced by others present acting the same. The zoo that I work at got a hilariously long complaint email one time from someone who couldn't believe there were no warning signs that there would be snakes present in the zoo, histrionically ran out screaming because they saw an animal in the place they paid to see animals and was outraged the zoo staff "wasn't sympathetic enough" to her situation. The sad part is this was a parent with her child and that's the kid's behavioral model in early life...

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4350878
No.
There was a study that estimated Tyrannosaurus intelligence to be between alligator and lower-end birds, but the brain structure, insofar as it can be reconstructed from the skull, had a lot more in common with alligators than birds:
Relative Size of Brain and Cerebrum in Tyrannosaurid Dinosaurs: An Analysis Using Brain-Endocast Quantitative Relationships in Extant Alligators. In Chapter 6 in J. M. Parrish, M. Henderson, P. J. Currie, and E. Koppelhus (eds.), Origin, Systematics, and Paleobiology of the Tyrannosauridae. Northern Illinois University Press
Then a retard took the comparative brain size value (EQ) for Tyrannosaurus Rex (when compared to reptiles) mentioned in this study and applied it to the comparative brain size value of chimps (when compared to mammals) which is retarded for obvious reasons:
The Rise and Fall of the Dinosaurs: A New History of a Lost World
The first study must be amended extent, in that Tyrannosaurs likely had higher neuron densities than alligators due to being warm-blooded, but the study notes that the TOTAL number of telencephalic neurons in a Tyrannosaurus would've been at most comparable to a baboon, at which point body size comes into play, which consumes neural resources:
Theropod dinosaurs had primate-like numbers of telencephalic neurons
And it is also worth noting that body temperature amongst theropods varied significantly, and not in a simple younger = warmer fashion. Tyrannosaurus was pretty lukewarm, whereas the much older Allosaurus had a noticeably higher body temperature, which may or may not have implications on neuron density (not an absolute, though. Monotremes are cleverer than many eutherians, affter all):
Fossil biomolecules reveal an avian metabolism in the ancestral dinosaur

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4367337
Larson jokingly suggests cows possess a material culture evolving towards the human and the modern. It's a running trope in his work.

Mocking both the evolution of cattle and the cultural but not individual progress of the human.

He probably eats beef while contemplating largely vegan themes, the idea not just that humans came from somewhere, but also that cows are going somewhere. And perhaps those two places may be similar even if they do not communicate. Elevating the bovine while subjugating the human. An ironic commentary not only on our own aspirations, but also on our lacunae. The blind spots that allow us to both farm cattle and pretend we aren't cattle ourselves.

it's brilliant, just laugh like you understand.
moo.

>>4367393
Those are all good. At least you didn't mention Existential Comics or Ctrl alt del. Far side is good too, but it can be very hit or miss. Usually people like one or two far side strips and that's all, here's mine.

I can explain why it's funny to me: Because it's something I wouldn't have thought of, but once it's explained to me it makes complete sense. The humour comes from thinking about how dogs bark, and comparing it to how humans use the word "Hey!" and realising humans and dogs are more alike than we tend to admit.

Meanwhile, the "Thagomizer" comic just isn't funny to me. I'm not even sure how it's a joke.

You're talking about "abstract art" as if what you enjoy is enjoyed for "good reasons" or, at least, objective ones. I'm not wanting to get into a discussion about intersubjectivity and culture, but I will say that your attitude makes you an insufferable wanker. The fact is the jokes that make you laugh make you laugh because it takes something familiar to you and somehow subverts it, your inability to apply this process to higher levels of abstraction does not make you better than anyone, no matter how much you think that might be the case.

Once upon a time in a far-off land, there was a brave and noble dog named Casper. Casper was the guardian of a flock of sheep that roamed the rolling hills and green pastures of the countryside.

One day, as Casper was patrolling the perimeter of the sheep's grazing grounds, he heard a faint yipping in the distance. As the sound grew louder, Casper knew that it was a pack of coyotes, fierce and cunning predators that would stop at nothing to snatch a meal from the sheep.

Without hesitation, Casper charged towards the coyotes, barking and growling fiercely. The coyotes, startled by Casper's boldness, hesitated for a moment before launching their attack.

Casper fought bravely, his sharp teeth and powerful jaws tearing into the coyotes' fur and flesh. The battle raged on, with the coyotes snarling and snapping at Casper, and Casper baring his teeth and lashing out with his paws.

Finally, after what seemed like an eternity, the last of the coyotes lay dying at Casper's feet. Casper had triumphed, and the sheep were safe.

Word of Casper's bravery and valor quickly spread throughout the land, and the sheepherders praised him as a hero. Casper was hailed as a champion, and his name became known throughout the kingdom as the greatest guardian of sheep that had ever lived.

Casper lived out the rest of his days in peace, watching over the flock and defending them from any threat that dared to cross his path. And though he was no longer a young dog, his spirit and courage never wavered, for he knew that he had been chosen to protect the sheep, and he would do so until his last breath.

Thus ends the epic tale of Casper the heroic dog, who single-handedly defeated eight coyotes to defend his beloved sheep flock. Though he may have been just a humble dog, he will forever be remembered as a true hero, and his legacy will live on in the hearts of all who knew him.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>4359785
It's Pachypodium lamerei or Pachypodium geayi. You'll need to bring it indoors in winter because they can't tolerate frost. (If it's a light and brief night frost, it can survive, but the growing tip(s) will die, so just don't risk it.) They also lose their leaves in winter and go dormant. There's a great cultivation guide for all Pachypodium spp. over here:
https://www.badperson.net/2021/02/pachypodium-complete-guide-to.html

Oh, and the difference between P. lamerei and P. geayi is that P. geayi has long, thin leaves. If, based on that description, you aren't sure which one you have, it's a P. lamerei.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4362100
If you're in a temperate climate, put all of your plants right up against the window. Understory jungle plants can be placed further back, but not too far - for example, five metres away from a window is really stretching it if you want it to survive longterm. But then it also depends on how large the windows are and what type of glass they're made of, and the colour of your walls and even your furniture also plays a role, and so on. My advice will always be to give your plants as much light as you possibly can, and if after several weeks/months (during the growing season) you still notice them struggling with sunburn, and you're sure you didn't underwater them or let some pest wreak havoc, then you can take the struggling plants a bit further away from the window, but again, not too far. There's already an enormous difference in the amount of light that will reach plants that are right up against the window, and the amount that will reach plants only half a metre away.

>>4362587
Sounds like you're seeing springtails, and what's killing your succulents is not them (they're beneficial), but overwatering caused in part by using a mainly peat-based soil. If you could post some pictures of the dying succulents and the insects, it'd be easier to tell what's going on.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4364160
Wait, what? The only thing in your list that's cold tolerant is mint, all the others die when it freezes.

If you're just looking for weedy plants with smelly leaves that you can grow indoors, look into other species of Coleus/Plectranthus like Plectranthus neochilus - depending on some factor, I think it's the time of day, it either smells like cannabis or rotting food scraps. The scent is incredibly powerful, but luckily it's only released when you touch it. Plectranthus socotranus smells strongly of cleaning products (again, only if you touch it), P. 'Cola' smells like, well, cola (and a bit of cleaning product), P. ernstii has a pleasant but difficult to describe scent, P. saccatus is citrusy, P. venteri smells like a citrusy cleaning product, etc.

Basically though, if you find a plant that's in the Lamiaceae family, it's almost guaranteed to have aromatic leaves and grow like a weed. Coleus, basil, mint, but also lavender, thyme, rosemary, salvia, catnip, all belong to the Lamiaceae.

If you're looking for something with pretty foliage that's easy to grow from cuttings, look up the gold variegated Pereskia, usually referred to as Pereskia aculeata var. godseffiana 'Variegata'. In spite of its looks, it's actually a cactus.
Other easy foliage plants to propagate are basically any Peperomia as well as Begonia. Most can grow from leaf cuttings, though some will only grow from stem cuttings.

>root and sell as seedlings
It's only a seedling if you grow it from seed, otherwise it's a cutting.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4364203
Don't worry, it can easily go two months without water. In fact, when growing them indoors, it's best not to treat them like (most) succulents with regards to watering, meaning don't water often, but when you do, soak them. After it's been dry for a couple of weeks/months, fill up a bowl with lukewarm water, just put your Tillandsia in there, and let it swim for a day, maybe two if it's been a long time since it last received water. After it's had a nice long bath, shake off the excess water and let it dry upside down. Repeat the process in a month or two and it'll grow just fine. Once you get the hang of it, you can (but don't have to) water more often to let it grow a bit faster, especially when it's nice and warm in the summertime. Tillandsia ionantha, like most Tillandsia, still grows very slowly, though.

Just to be sure that it's actually T. ionantha and not one of the million other species that are often mislabelled, is it pretty much identical to the one in this picture?

>>4368345
It doesn't matter, epiphytic cacti, except for the really thick ones that just look like upside down desert cacti, will grow in anything and can be kept dry or permanently moist, they really don't care at all. Eventually they eat all of the soil anyway, leaving nothing but roots, and when that happens you don't even need to repot them unless you have an Epiphyllum oxypetalum that you want to grow xboxhuge.

For a Schlumbergera though, it'll do just fine in the pot and medium it's in right now forever.

>>4368361
Plenty of succulents like a higher pH. Regardless, the pH of normal potting mix is pretty low, so adding some limestone would probably only raise it to neutral.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4374088
Some clean them up from the shell, some don't. In my experience, leaving them in the shell had been better.
I used sphagnum moss as it stays moise easier.
You want to keep it moist, but not drenched.

They are very fragile once they start sprouting, keep a good humidity and make sure it doesn't dry out.
I've had best luck with a flat container, like a tray.
Keep a lookout for pests as it'd destroy them easily at the early stages.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4379681
A lot of these sort of monocots are typically propagated by division rather than seed.
Often they have become so successful at vegetative reproduction that natural selection/genetic drift has rendered their seeds sterile or only marginally viable.
Dunno if that's the case with yours, but I wouldn't bother with seeds, I'd just split it.
But read up on how to split them first so you do it good.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
To evolve eusociality
>have something immovable and worth defending, e..g. a nest, burrow or similar; this can be dropped later, but appears to be a necessary initial stage
>flight, for long-term sustainability. There are exceptions - mole rats - but they're stupidly inbred. Social spiders are seemingly a hair's breath from eusociality, but again, stupid inbreeding rates. Long-term successful eusocial species are without exception flight-capable (or aquatic; sadly I can't find sources on inbreeding in eusocial shrimps)
There are bird species featuring both, communal nest building (e.g. some bee eaters; they even assist each other in building their burrows) and flight, yet no eusociality in sight.
May or may not have to do with the limited size of their clutches, but some species get up to mole rat-esque numbers, so it shouldn't be strictly unsurmountable.
So I'm thinking about the evolution of eusocial birds. Coloniesof a couple dozen to a couple hundred individuals, maybe a few thousand (requiring multiple gynes), building immense communal nests either in trees or as underground burrows in riverside cliffs and similar (again, bee eaters as my go-to probable candidate). Reproductive suppression would be an issue, particularly for tree-nesting species, as hormonal suppression becomes difficult, but raw aggression by the gyne is oftentimes sufficient. Burrowing species would have it easier in this regard.
End result is nests hosting thousands of birds with maybe a dozen gynes living along the Amazons or in the African savannah, the workers always busy containing seeds, insects, and occasionally bullying big cats and vultures off large carcasses to make off with the meat. Any animal getting too close to the nest risks being divebombed by a few dozen birds with sharp beaks, unless it's one of the trapping species that just wait for herbivores to step into one of their tunnels and then pick meat off the trapped zebra's calves.

posts.com:
What are some specbio projects you like and dislike?
Like:
>Polinices
This project is pretty fascinating and knows how to design alien sealife that looks kinda familiar to tropical sealife on earth, but also definitely alien. I personally think it overuses the colonial organism trope and has way too little sealife that doesn't just fit within the human size range. However, many of the animals, like the sea wheel and the sponge that has a chain of drones wheeling through it, are legit fascinating and cool. The biological internet idea from the sponges is pretty wack though, it'd be odd to have Twatter underwater and suddenly have the sponges call you a nigger in unison before their little drone workers swarm you.
>Expedition
Come on, everyone loves this one. I'm not even going to bother explaining. Only thing is, I think the Alien Planet mockumentary did the right thing to downscale some of the creatures and redesign the littoralopes to act less like sheep and more like plain antelope analogues. Do wish Darwin IV had more seas though, I'm pretty sure smaller seas, lagoons and rivers wouldn't have jeopardized the alien nature of the planet that much.
>Blue Moon (Extraterrestrial)
I like the idea of gigantic plants with cyanophyll catching rainwater and turning into miniature ponds for lifeforms to squat in. The stalkers basically being alien whalers is a fascinating idea, with them using 360° vision to spot out their quarry and avoid the branches of their plant ponds. The only thing I didn't like was that the biosphere was way too limited. There should've been more critters lurking throughout the shadowed areas of the skypond trees at different levels, with flyers and climbers adapted to the darkness. And personally, I think the underfloor of the forest should've been a swamp of sorts. And that's not to mention that the planet clearly had oceans and other biomes that could've been explored.

Fellow mammals, this is the new invertebrate thread
I saw a thread a while back talking about everything invertebrate wise, and it seemed like a cool subject to talk about the world of bugs
I’ll start us off with this thread about solitary bees of California since it is my realm of “expertise” to kick us off
But of course, for any other entomology frens that also breathes this, chime in and talk about the bugs you find interesting or anything relating to invertebrates

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4369089
Exactly what are solitary bees?
You may have heard the bee poster child’s like honeybees and bumblebees
These bees are perfect examples of what you would call eusocial bees, meaning they’re bees that work together in a hive supporting a queen bee
You can imagine this as a communist dystopia of a sort, all the workers bowing down to one rule
Solitary bees, on the other hand, sounds and behave very similarly to eusocial bees, but not quite
Solitary bees are what I call them a one (wo)man army, because solitary bees, the ones doing all the carry in terms of foraging and reproduction, are all female bees who construct very intricate nests with brood cells to lay their eggs on
Many of these solitary bees roam alone building their own nest on abandoned ground cavities or trees
There has been evidence of solitary bees communing to one nest, but they live apart from each other
Think of it as an apartment building, where multiple tenants live together but don’t want to deal with each other
While this exist, almost all solitary bees work alone and manage their own nests
Op pic btw is a leaf cutter bee, since bees in this genus solely collect pollen in their abdomen, Megachile
This pic is a ground digger bee, or Habropoda

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4369092
In burgerland, there exist around 6k bee species, 1/3 of those bees exist and are native to California
While California has its ups and down (politically mainly), it’s hard to argue against the fact that it is a biodiversity hotspot of not just bugs, but also plants and vertebrates
And in these areas, especially coastal habitats, exist a vast array of solitary bees, from time fly sized ones to big chunky ones
Just like flowers, these bees emerge during the spring time, and take about 2-3 weeks to complete a nest
A completed nest means a nest with finished built cells with provisions ready for the larvae
A single solitary bee makes its foraging trip almost all morning and early afternoon, and only feeds around the afternoon, as soon as it emerges from their nest
Only females actually pollinate plants, and males in this case only exist to fuck as many bees
Although there is some evidence of males pollinating plants,90% of the time they find mates

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4369099
Wild bees pollinate about 80% of the worlds flowering plants, as well as crop fields
They account to about $10 billion worth of pollination services each year, and they do it for free
Some them are specialized to pollinate particular flowers and others are more generalized
What I find these fellas interesting is just how much diversity there is around the world, especially the way they build their nests
Some build their nests on sands and the ground, others make essentially mud huts, others nest on snailshells, and some make cavities on trees and bark
The fact that these guys do this all around is pretty cool, since I wasn’t aware of this when I started my grad work years ago

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4369104
With these bees present also comes with natural predators
Some noticeable predators, aside birds, revolve in the microbio world
Mites, funguses and some bacteria are dangerous for nest builders by essentially either killing the eggs or adult female
Aside that, also exist an entire family of cleptoparisitic bees
Just like cuckoo birds, these cuckoo bees invade nest cavities and replace the host eggs with their own
These guys are pretty vicious, in terms of invading and attacks
Even though they have no pollination abilities, they are a good indicator in telling us how well local bees are faring
Basically, if you find a few parasitic bees on a sample site, it would indicate a healthy solitary bee population in the vicinity
Pic related is a common parasitic bee, Sphecodes

>>bought their regular bag of dry kibble but it looked a little different than usual
did it smell like usual? any recalls issued for that food? anyone else posting about similar issues? changed the ingredients recently? look into stuff like that, it can help to check sometimes.

reasonably certain my vet would advise me to see how he does over the next few days and to bring him in if it's getting worse instead of better, or if it persists longer than a week, and to call back with any changes or questions in the meantime. oh and if, say, their schedule was packed and soonest available appt wouldn't be for three days or whatever, we'd book me one as a placeholder and then i'd call the day before to cancel if it wasn't needed. re: stool sample, not sure there. hasn't come up much. i'd just ask about it before hanging up.

what's your vet like? as in, how come you're asking the interbutts for advice instead of calling and asking your vet?

canned is always better than kibble so good job there. switching abruptly to a new food can be a coin toss whether your pet's gonna get the shits or not. hard to say whether the suspect dry food wouldn't have given both of them the shits if not for the probiotics but considering she wasn't nearly as badly affected and he's shown improvement after the 1 serving, seems like a good course of action to keep them both on it for long enough to transition to the new food. careful not to overdo it on the pumpkin, cats are obligate carnivores and need very little in the way of plant based nutrients.

So I have two small conundrums between my older (2yo) cat and my kitten (11w).
The first is that I can't quite keep their food separate, and if I have both out at the same time, then they'll just eat each other's food. Which while it's not too big of an issue, I want to make sure my kitten is getting the right kind of food. Would it be bad for the cats if I just alternated the food each day, if they're both receptive to both kinds?
As a side note, for the moment they're both eating dry food. I try to use it as sparingly as possible, but I just had my car break down and I'm having to budget pretty hardcore. It's not ideal, but neither of them like cheap wet food so I'm doing what I can to keep them fed.
The second conundrum is their "playing". They seem rather friendly with each other most of the time and my older cat has taken to cleaning the kitten, though she usually quickly swats him away. They're not exactly cuddling, but they tolerate each others' existence. The problem is though that when they're chasing each other around, I'm thoroughly worried about whether they're being too rough or too aggressive with each other. They'll get into a clinch sometimes, but what worries me here is my own inexperience with how cats play fight with each other. Also the fact that the fights aren't exactly evenly match and I'm not sure whether my older cat knows how to restrain himself.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4372325
Cats are tough creatures and their play fighting always looks harsher than it actually is. Your kitten isn't strong enough to hurt your adult and the adult knows not to harm the kitten, plus a good swat from the adult is important to teach the kitten when its gone too far. Corporal punishment is the norm in the natural world.
Do keep an eye on them for any injuries, competitiveness over the food (cats are naturally communists and think everything is theirs, but if one cat is actively driving the other away then you've got a problem), and their body language after a fight.
If the ears are folding back and the tail is twitching at the base then the cat is fucked off and it's not having fun. If the pupils are dilated and the tail is twitching at the tip then the cat is having fun.
Cats are normally solitary creatures and will usually only tolerate each other unless they're siblings.
Also your cats do need wet food as it's where they get their water from. They don't like drinking still water so unless you want them drinking out of the tap you need to give them wet food.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4373994
Pet store dewormer drops. 1 pipette on the back of the neck every 6 months. The vet stuff is far stronger and is best used if they develop an infestation.
Supermarket stuff is the lowest quality. It's usually more expensive than the pet store stuff because you need to use it every 3 months instead of 6 so you gotta buy more.
Treat worms when they become an issue. If your cat hunts it's gonna get worms, but your cat might not be a hunter and if so a preventative oral dewormer with known risks is also a waste of money.
I've been dewormed before so I can say it's not a pleasant process.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Lost my second kot today. My first one, I fucked everything about his death up so incredibly badly and hated myself for months after (ignored his symptoms for too long, didn't manage the disease well, waited too long at the end and let his condition snowball into a crisis+emergency euthanasia, I even fucked up his burial because I'm a retard who doesn't know how to dig a hole). This time around I was intent on doing it right. Got his issues identified early (kidney disease + bladder cancer later on), managed his condition as well as I could, consulted with a vet about the right time to pull the plug, scheduled an appt to euthanize him before his issues became truly critical. His urethra had become mostly occluded due to the cancer, the prognosis for tumor removal on a 16yo cat with underlying kidney disease was abysmal, and the cancer was at the point where at any point in time it could grow another mm, fully obstruct his urethra and cause a ruptured bladder. So I said my goodbyes this morning, took him in, euthanasia took 30 minutes, everything was easy and he didn't suffer.

And holy fuck, I still feel like a cunt. It all just felt so fucking casual, like I was just fitting some cat murder into my schedule right between lunch and a haircut. None of the techs nor the vet had any bedside manner, they were fucking joking about survivor and tiktok on the other side of the door while I tried to say goodbye. But I guess no matter what I do I'm going to feel like a cunt. Either I let him suffer too long or I terminate his life prematurely even though he might have been able to eke out a few more weeks of feeling ok-ish. And either way it makes me a cunt. Idunno. I just can't get over how casual it all felt, I almost wish there had been a crisis so I could feel like I was saving him from pain instead of just randomly terminating his existence on a whim.

And of course I'm going from one cat to zero this time. The house is empty and it feels fucked. Fuck me.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>4375508
the experience was just different too, my first cat was euthanized at an emergency vet and they had a specialized room far away from the rest of the clinic with dim lighting and little fake candles and a call button so you could spend as much time as you wanted saying goodbye. I can't say it was great or fun but I came away feeling like it was done well. This time it was at my usual vet and it was just... in a fucking exam room in the middle of all the rest of the rooms. with conversations about anal glands and rabies vaccines traveling through the walls. it just felt cramped and sterile and rushed and like nobody gave a fuck, which made it feel like maybe I didn't give a fuck either if I was bringing him to a place like this.

So maybe if you're in the market, shop around and ask the techs what the experience is like. I would really recommend a specialized quiet room if you can find one and if it doesn't cost too much/too much more.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4375795
Sort of.
Cats and their owners will create a small vocabulary with their pet. If you have a cat you probably pick up on his "I'm hungry!" meow. Not that that specific sound means anything, but the cat cottons on fast that when he makes one noise he gets one result, and with another noise, he gets something else.
If you and your neighbor swap cats, the meows change meaning because its a private and personal vocabulary, and not the universal word for "FOOD!" in cat.
But yes, the vast majority of cat vocalizations are strictly for our benefit (because cats think we're fucking retarded).
Certain cats are also more chatty than others obviously, but between cats they don't really make a lot of noise besides hissing and yowling to spook a threat, and caterwauling for sexy-time after they're kittens.

Everything around me reminds me of her because of how much time we spent together in the same 2 rooms of the house and now everything just feels empty without her and I am in complete shambles whenever I jump up to check on her and realize that shes just not there. It didn't even upset me this much when actual family members died and its just got me feeling completely lost, so at the very least I wanted to commemorate her with other catbros.

She was unlike any other animal thats ever been in my life, and had such a unique personality that if she was treated like a pet instead of a family member, she'd be genuinely offended and would make sure it became my problem until I spent some time just giving her attention. She was an absolute monster/alpha chad of a cat when it came to socialising with any other animal and would routinely harass any other animal in her presence until they submitted and/or ran away but had the sweetest temperant Ive ever seen in a cat when she was around people, and Im confident that Ill never own another animal like her again. >>>

posts.com: Has anyone had their rats on a long-distance trip yet? posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4352024
definitely get them used to the carrier/cage/whatever you're transporting them in, let them explore it during free roam and encourage them to enter it by putting treats inside
when I trained my rats to get used to the carrier at first they took the treats and skipped away because it was still unknown territory, but after a while they even started napping inside during free roam
I suppose scent marking is one reason why they got comfortable with the carrier
also god damn these guys poop a lot, I had a large cat carrier and my 3 boys shat all over it during the 2 hour drives I took to visit my parents
oh yeah another thing is to not forget about water and maybe food too, but I'm sure you have those sorted out

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4352024
Rats are pretty good at travelling. Make sure the cage isn't too tall though, as the car's movement will make them unsteady on their feet, you don't want them falling. Also put a towel over the top, which will keep the light off/noise down. The light outside constantly changing can be scary for them.

Also make sure the cage is secured in place, you don't want it to go flying if you do an emergency stop! Same with checking that all the cage doors are secured before you head off, you don't want escapees whilst doing 70 down the road.

Mites can sometimes be a secondary cause for illness- they can get bad because the mouse is sick and can't shrug them off like normal, or the stress of having them lowers the immune system and makes them more susceptible to other illnesses. posts.name: Anonymous

>>4360406
I know what you mean, but these are my lab rats and they're bred in extremely strict conditions to be incredibly resistant to disease. Just wanted to clear up this misunderstanding between laboratory animals and general albino feeders, if people are interested in rescuing. Laboratory rats cost b/w $300-$2000 per rat. In labs they're housed in shoe box sized tanks with only the barred roof for ventilation. It's only cleaned once a week, but even with the immense ammonia buildup these rats never succumb to respiratory illness. Probably the only advantage of having biomedical research grade sprague dawleys. If they experienced any health issues beyond the ones being studied, it would ruin experiments, so it's ensured that these strains are highly resistant to all diseases and cancers. They are born completely mycoplasma free as well. The downsides are that they're extremely skittish, poorly socialized, have poor vision, and have had little to no enrichment for most of their lives (so they're pretty deprived).

And my eggs come from rescued battery farm hens that ignore the nesting boxes and just shit them out in the garden. Every morning is like an easter egg hunt. t. Australian dairy farmer though. Anon it's gonna take time. Sit around them. Let them come up to you. Don't try and force love on them.

I started by sitting in a room with mine and a cup of treats near me. They would come up to the treats since they are food driven. I would gently try to pet the face, if they don't like it back off a bit.

However it's a personality thing, one of mine was a nervous and territorial wreck. Now he hops on my chest and asks for pets. My other was a big sweetheart cuddler kissy boy right out the gate.

Photo of my new girl, and my nervous boy who now chins the fuck out of everything. Good luck anon

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Look at this long fucking idiot.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4296159
You need to build familiarity by being around them, and they'll eventually trust and feel safe.
Making yourself "small" by laying down can help. Don't try to pet or touch them much if they aren't receptive. If you do pet, I start by the sides of their cheeks and come in from the side. Bringing your hand down from the top can be either be interpreted as scary or domineering.
I try to not directly stare at the buns.
Basically I don't want to trigger anything in their prey instinct. Kind of ask yourself if you're behaving like a cat or like a cow would around the rabbit.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4296159
Some rabbits are naturally more social than others. If your pic is your rabbit you're in luck, because lops are on average more friendly.

1. spend a lot of time in their area just hanging out
2. bribe them with treats. Obviously you can't ruin their diet, but make them associate you with good things.
3. be very patient

I have a netherland dwarf who is afraid of her own shadow but she'll run up to me for treats and eventually started coming to me for snuggles. I also have a lop that was hand raised and he begs for attention 24/7 and required 0 effort. They all have unique personalities so don't force a rabbit to act a certain way and just be non-threatening and patient. I also advise not picking rabbits up except when you need to. You can make a rabbit tolerate it if you do it often but they don't like it and they'll associate you with something that is scary.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4318654
In general you should have female rabbits spayed unless you're planning on breeding. Their chance of cancer and subsequently their life expectancy is horrendous when intact (chance of uterine cancer is 65% by age of four, meanwhile most spayed female dwarf rabbit breeds tend to have a life expectancy of around 8-10 years).

Two females are also far more likely to bond easily when both are spayed. Two females are actually the most difficult to bond ironically. It is easier to bond a male/female pair (obviously) or two males.

TL:DR; See >>4319187

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4318391
>>4318438
>>4318616
Do you feed a lot of vegetables/fruits? He may be getting most of his water from food. Also, don't anthropomorphize your bun. Things that make YOU want to drink the water is not what he wants. They don't want sweet or flavored water, they want clean water. I see you're using a bowl so that's good, they generally prefer bowls over bottles. You may try to have moving water. Many animals prefer moving water. Something as simple as a water bottle suspended above, slowing dripping through a pinhole could be enough (although you'd have to get a larger water bowl as the bun definitely wouldn't want it dripping on his head), but if you want to spend money, there are tons of pet fountains available.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Anons, how do you deal with G.I. Stasis?
My rabbit died of it (back in 2008 so long time ago) and I'm dreaming of getting another one (or two kek) but scared it'll happen again.
Is it too late when they get hunched up and become inactive? Is there a way of curing them of that?
Thanks in advance.
Pic not rel.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4375159
Keep their litterbox filled with hay and/or have an unlimited supply of hay for them nearby. Try to limit too many carbs in their diet such as fruits and carrots. Keep them active, hydrated, and happy.

Treating it means a trip to the vet. It involves dealing with the bacteria in their guts, but only if its clear the issue isn’t dehydration or something else. This involves feeding antibiotics such as cholestyramine and feeding probiotics. It also involves drinking lots of water and sprinkling herbs in their food to get them to eat more (or use liquified food). There could be complications such as blockage and severe pain, which are treated with prokinetics and painkillers, at worst surgery which can be a very expensive decision and may be kinder to euthanize.

posts.com:

>>4375159
Vigilance is the main thing, since the earlier it is caught the better the outcome. If bunny is just a bit strange then you need to be on top of it and monitoring. I have one rabbit that seems prone to gas or stasis, so I check him a lot if he is doing anything abnormal. If you catch it early it could be fixed at home without requiring a trip to the vet by syringe feeding simethicone gas drops, water, and critical care or similar food. With my gassy rabbit I have massaged his belly to manually get it going.

tl;dr yes they probably did
Dinosaurs lacked a syrinx, the organ responsible for bird vocalization.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kB7FahbwRBs
12:57 This is what modern birds sound like when they lack a syrinx.
Tone it down proportionate to how big the T-rex was and you have a VERY deep hiss/grumble. T-rex also had sensory organs that were attuned to drastically low frequencies.

Cassowaries have a syrinx but it's primitive, and you can tell right away.
If any of you think a large bird that grumbles isn't scary, try calling a cassowary a humming pussy within disembowling distance.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4380009
where your info got tossed out is when rice pollen was found in dinosaur coprolites from the late jurassic in india and then found in sediments all over the world by the middle cretaceous.

this moves the evolution of angiosperms back almost 100 million years before they appear as plant fossils. Grasses other than rice have also been found in the cretaceous, and were apparently global and dominant by the end of the cretaceous.

palynological studies also indicate declines in ferns and conifers at the same rate that angiosperms spread. Again, all during the cretaceous and well before the first angiosperm fossils appear.

The current view is that angiosperms, much like birds, evolved during the late jurassic but didn't really leave a global record until the early to mid cretaceous and left few if any body fossils until the end of the cretaceous.

The other interesting thing about endothermy in fishes is how often it evolved.

last I checked (back in the 1990's) there were at least 7 different genera of endothermic tunas, and each one evolved endothermy in a different way, meaning it evolved at least 7 different times. Sharks are similar in evolving endothermy several times.

so there is a strong evolutionary pressure for large aquatic predators to become warm blooded. Meaning it might actually be a bit weird if giant marine reptiles WEREN'T warm blooded.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4379416
Also of course there's the crocodile heart, which is a 4 chambered heart that evolved a hole (shunt) that turns it back into a 3 chamber heart.

this is interesting because 4 chamber hearts are adaptations to warm blood, they keep warm and cold blood separate to aid in raising body temperatures. This feature being present and then lost in crocodiles may indicate that they used to be warm blooded, and indeed all archosaurs may have started off warm blooded and then some became cold blooded over time. If true, this could happen in other reptile lineages as well.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>4379604
>>4379753
I mean oxygen isotopes vary in natural water according to temperature because lighter isotopes evaporate faster from warm water and condense slower into cold water.

But there's no evaporation and condensation going on inside the body of an animal, so the isotope ratio doesn't change once the water is consumed and it won't change until it's excreted. So oxygen isotopes are a great record of the temperature of water an animal drinks or eats, but don't say shit about the internal temperature of the animal.

Our paleo schizo doesn't know this so he's latched onto a terrible study with laughable methodology simply because it supports a wrong belief he already had.

>Is that a reasonable approach to the problem?

theoretically kinda maybe. but also no. my dog learned to extort chicken meat treats by threatening to run in the street after I used those treats to reward her for a recall when she was getting too close to the street. took her 3 repetitions to figure it out. gist is, do not, ever, give in to their extortion. instead, structure your days such that when they whine you know there is no chance they have to go #1 or #2. space your scheduled outdoor times such according to their age and bladder control and meals. spend an appropriate amount of time outside, do physical and mental training according to your dog's current needs. a 10min session of obedience can tire a dog out more than a 30min run and it's better for their joints especially when they are still young/growing.

>>4378639
Too many things are wrong or incomplete with this study but in order to avoid repeating what this anon said >>4378641, the size of the cerebrum (and its proportion to body size) is not the only correlation needed when judging a species' intelligence. Gyrification (the development of the gyri and sulci or brain wrinkles and folds) is important too since that is one of the things that correlate with neuron quantity (more surface area allows for more neurons in a smaller space and thus more synapses). While birds have a reasonable cerebrum to body ratio they lack these folds that are present on primates. So even if dinosaurs had the same ratio as birds do inside their cranium it makes 0 sense to compare them to primates that do have these folds (less when compared to humans though) and it makes no sense to estimate their cognitve functions with just the criteria this study discusses.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4378639
Numerous issues. Mostly with the interpretation of the study, a few with the study itself.
>'Primate Levels' here refers to the total number of neurons, not the number of neurons relative to body size. Since the dinosaurs in the study are considerably larger than primates, the neurons per unit of body mass ratio is dramatically lower for dinosaurs. Consequence: Dramatically less intelligence in dinosaurs than in primates
>the author treated sauropod neural density as being in the ectoterm range despite the very study he cites with regards to ecto/endothermic growth patterns showing sauropods to be endotherms. This seems questionable.
>while estimating neuron densities based on metabolic activity is reasonable enough, it is very much a hypothesis, not a fact. Neuron densities could easily have taken a while to catch up to metabolisms. Supporting evidence would be needed
>this supporting evidence isn't very supporting. E.g. Tyrannosaurus brain structure, insofar as we can reconstruct it from its skulls, is more alligator- than bird-esque. Its encephalisation quotient is high when compared to extant reptiles, but low when compared to extant birds
>the study bases its estimates of neuron density on metabolic rates. But metabolic rates amongst dinosaurs varied wildly (again, shown in the very study on dinosaur metabolic rates this paper cites), and Allosaurus in the Jurassic had a significantly higher metabolic rate/body temperature than Tyrannosaurus in the Cretaceous. Nevermind ornithischia almost universally showing ectothermic metabolic rates (which this study acknowledges and thus gives ornithischia ectothermic neuron densities, mind).
Most of these aren't really issues with the paper itself (papers narrowly focussing on a single aspect and requiring other papers to form a complete picture are normal), my only real objection to the paper itself is its treatment of sauropods, which blatantly goes against the study's stated methodology because reasons.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4379241
cont.
But the interpretation thereof is, as is probably to be expected for dinosaurs and within popsci, wild. The 'Primate number of neurons' clickbait without mentioning relative body sizes doesn't help, of course (and I'll absolutely blame the study's authors for that one).
If viewed in conjunction with other papers, some of which this paper even cites as a major source, the end result is that theropod intelligence ranked somewhere between clever modern reptiles (alligators, varanids) and pretty dumb birds. Certainly nowhere near primates, which incidentally, every reputable institution keeps screaming about is nonsense, but popsci just won't shut up about clever girls.
Steven Spielberg and Michael Crichton have a lot to answer for.

>>4378763
Okay here >>4378753 you mention there is mold growth on the back of your hive, mold indicates there must be a high presence of moisture. Moisture is the ultimate killer of bees. Where I live most bee keepers take their bees into the interior for the winter where it is much dryer, even though it’s much colder in the interior because it’s drier the bees are much better off. When the bees get wet they are unable to heat up. A wet cold is very very bad. The beekeepers that keep their bees here typically have a setup to reduce as much moisture as possible from entering the hive. They do things like reducing vegetation around the hives and having a pad that is rock or concrete or anything that doesn’t hold as much moisture as grass or dirt, the best is a bee house. A little shelter that has a floor that is raised off the ground a good amount and a big roof, that way there is alway a large dry perimeter around the beehives and the bee boxes don’t ever get wet. Even though the bee boxes are by design to keep moisture out the second layer of defence of a bee house ensures that minimum moisture gets in and is necessary in areas where there is lots of precipitation

Snowy owls are one of the few animals that unironically ignite my moé instincts. Not only do they look like adorable little angels, they also have the personalities of ones as well. Chick-on-chick infanticide is relatively rare in this species, and on top of that the siblings are known to share their given meals with each other. All the more impressive taking into consideration that they live in an environment that is only slightly more forgiving than the polar ice caps, or planet Hoth.

The species are sexually dimorphic to better suit their familial roles. The male is nearly solid white to blend into the tundra helping him to hide, but that also aids him in hunting lemmings. While the female is a speckled guardian who broods on a nest above permafrost, usually while tenderly pruning her offspring. However, like all parents the will fight beak and claw if any intruder ventures too close, from arctic foxes to polar bears, to the typical human.

If the don't melt your heart, I don't know what will.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>4372256
That is an excellent question for multiple reasons:

1. It will be a fun project to reconstruct the vocal cords of this animal, there was even a YouTube video speculating on how T.Rex most likely sounded like a double bass, due to modern birds (of the large variety) using closed mouth vocals to communicate over a large distance, similar to elephants.

2. But on a more opinionated note. I find it disappointing that there was no grand designs towards this animal, and it reminds me of the enthusiastically, cheesy early iguanodon interpretations. It's better to imagine the creature as a 19th century Godzilla while being based on a single jawbone, rather than a lackluster paragraph on Wikipedia. Imagination is important to tell stories and to fill in the intellectual gaps, (as long as there is systematic evidence).

Crete is an underrated paleo landscape were big was small and vise versa, and it's eerie to think that the ancient Greeks noted the lack of hostile fauna of the island, and they all seemed to have disappeared like the Minoans.

Individual bats aren’t very good at thermoregulation, and generally rely on other bats to maintain their body temps. Some vets are aware that smaller dogs shouldn't receive all their vaccines in a day. Others are. We do not 100% understand the risks of all the vaccines. Or really care. Most people put up with it because "it's just an animal".

>>4375024
You're taking the whole "true foxes" designation too literally.

Think of it this way: "fox" is a bodytype that organisms can evolve into. We can define "fox" as something like "warm-blooded, medium-small quadrupedal furred omnivore with slit pupils, a long pointed muzzle, a long bushy tail, etc". Any animal that evolves into this bodytype /is/ a fox. Here's a mindfuck: genus Vulpes may not have even been the first to evolve into foxes, and certainly won't be the last. If animals evolved on other planets, some probably evolved into the fox bodytype too.

What I dislike about binomial nomenclature is how crappy many of the name choices were. Translating a dumb name choice into Latin doesn't make it smart. Linnaeus' choice of "Vulpes vulpes" is especially regretable; it's biased, eurocentric, and gives off the impression that red foxes are the paragon of foxliness that all other foxes are to be compared to. Whereas really, red foxes are just one of many types of fox. And choices like Lycalopex ('wolfox') are dumb too, since they define the animal in comparison to other animals.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4378742
With red foxes, the paw-bottom fur grows long as the season gets colder to the point where fur covers the pawpads completely. This helps them both conserve heat and walk on snow. Then come spring the fox sheds and the paw-bottom fur sheds too. There's vids of foxes chewing between their toes to help rip the fur out. Even when it's all shed their pawpads are much hairier than dogs' - fur actually grows out of the edges of the pawpads. The fox in this photo has the least hairy pawpads I could find.

With fennecs, their pawpads are almost always completely covered in fur. This is for the opposite reason of red foxes: to protect their pawpads from the heat of the desert sand.

With gray foxes, these finally do have big black pawpad beans like dogs: https://4.bp.blogspot.com/-YzP11MliY6s/W_m2i43RuqI/AAAAAAAABzk/t6iHzEJryU03U_8_i40-9xj4QcvxaXLUACLcBGAs/s0/foxNewcollarsm2018NPS.jpg

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4375386
They aren't too demanding from what I understand, I've seen people keep then in bare tanks and feed then papertowels. I kept them in dirt, because worms, but those extra nutrients is what I blame for the bacteria outbreak. Definitely run an air stone with them, but be careful with sponge filters because the worms will live in the sponge if it's porous enough. I'd just do 100% water changes a week because I kept them in a 5gal. When you do a water change, either stir the gravel around or use some scissors to cut the worms up. They replicate through segmentation so the worm peices turn to new worms. Not sure if these are tips but it's what I'd do different

>use fine and sharp gravel, not dirt
>keeping solo without snails
>no light
>harvest more frequently
>keep with plants(moss or floating)

What I gathered so far, did I miss anything? Any mistake?
Vampire:
+slower metabolism
Grows slowly, live longer (need less food?)
+more active feeding
Filtering action is more interesting
+color
Can be beautiful blue or pink/light orange
+-color can change in every molt, blue color seems limited to hard water, mostly dull colors with no markings or patterns unless specific cases
+-bigger max size
(Need more food?)
-Shy and nocturnal
You won’t see them much, might stay hidden most of the time
-clumsy
Might fuck up the decoration, uproot plants, etc.

Bamboo
+smaller max size
(Need less food?)
+more active
Will stay in the open more often, both during day and night
+Color
Some have a white stripe, body color is usually striated, can be red
+-color
Can actively change colors depending on environment
-faster metabolism
Doesn’t live as long (still can live pretty long compared to many aquarium inhabitants), grows faster (Need more food?)
-More passive feeding
Not as cool in action

Right now I’m leaning towards the bamboo shrimp. Both are cool but I assume I will be seeing it most of the time while the vampire one will be out of view most of the time. About color, I guess I could use color enhancing food to try to make it look prettier while the vampire one depends on many other factors since its best color is not a shade of red.

>>4375729
The thing is that dust food will not work that well when it is spread over the entire aquarium and not direct fed to it. Fish will probably eat it, shrimp will probably eat it and it will deposit on plants so I assume only a small fraction will end up consumed by the filtering shrimp. Also the vampire shrimp are beefy so I assume they would be much better at escaping than the more delicate bamboo shrimp. That aquarium did had a lid but it didn’t stop the shrimp. Either they are strong enough to lift a lid if it doesn’t have a weight or it found a place where it is easier to lift it. Anyway I’m trying to find ways to make the aquarium inhabitants happy and not want to leave the tank to begin with. The tank I’m planning to set up should be hard to escape but I don’t want to have it trying to escape. I bought a 60L spherical tank. And I want to put plants, a school of green neon tetras, dwarf shrimp, filtering shrimp and a few snails and dwarf hillstream loaches. Snails will be Clithon retropictum (japanese neritina) it isn’t the most beautiful neritina but it have a long lifespan, 1 snail of other types so they won’t reproduce and avoid snails that can reproduce alone. I could simplify it with only Neritinas but I like having one ramshorn snail, one japanese trapdoor snail, and one Biwamelania as special characters you see now and then.

While not self sustainable the tank will have a kind of nutrient flow. Fish waste becomes nutrient for plants and algae, algae becomes nutrient for shrimp and snails (or filtering shrimp in case of green water), Neritina babies become food for filtering shrimp and fish (negligible I think) IF the loach doesn’t eat the eggs anyway and finally fish eat some of the shrimp babies. Also filtering shrimp eats own babies. I guess shrimp eat fish eggs as well. They would still die if I don’t feed them but at least they have a tiny little amount of food when I can’t do it myself.

>>4376317
For pleco breeding you put a cave into the tank and the male will chase a female into it and get her to lay eggs. Then he kicks her out and wedges himself in while he fans the eggs until they hatch. Most breeders would pull the cave a little while after the eggs hatch and put them into a seperate tank for grow out.
If you're willing to do plenty of water changes almost any size tank works. It's just really important that the water is clean when they're that young, otherwise you get defects or dead fish.

I checked aquariumscience.org and the site is a meme as well. The first line in the site is:
>This is a website dedicated to freshwater aquariums. It is based on SCIENCE AND LOGIC, not on parroted internet “advice”, anecdotal “It worked great for me“
That sounds nice even if the tone sounds like a 4chan shitpost. So I checked the fish food section to see if there is something interesting and the first line is:
>Because of a long and complicated line of cause and effect, the protein level of the food turns out to be the major contributor to the health of a fish. The more protein, the clearer the water. The clearer the water the healthier the fish. When I buy commercial food I always buy the highest protein food I can find, regardless of the species of fish.
Zero links to scientific resources supporting his claims, literally anecdotal “It worked great for me“
A little latter in the "myths" section we have this:
>There is such a thing as “high quality” and “low quality” protein.
Anyone who had basic biochemistry should know that not all proteins are made equal, you can't give an animal a diet where all the protein in its diet is made entirely by alanine and expect the animal to produce the other aminoacids.
There are plenty of studies on the effects of different protein sources in fish development and boy, there is a lot of difference. With the expansion of aquaculture the demand for fish feed increased, the main source of protein was fish meal but now the fish meal demand exceeded the production so scientists started looking for alternatives. One of the most promising options are onions meal, cheap and complete protein but replacing all fish meal with onions meal have negative effects on fish, some species have negative effects even with partial substitution, to solve that alternatives have been proposed that result in better digestibility and less negative reactions like onions protein concentrate, fermented basedbean meal and insect meal.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4376630
afaik dave doesn't post here. His site is hit or miss, I agree with a lot of it even if not how he got there. I think the main utility that is hard to find elsewhere are his pages on diseases and his general treatment advice (ie, antibiotics in the water basically do jack shit for an internal bacterial infection except reduce total bacterial load which may allow a fish's natural immune system to fight off infection). I also agree with his take on filtration.

The polemic stuff can be fun to read but isn't 100% right. He underplays nitrogenous waste as a factor in fish health I think, but gives proper attention to having clear, low bacteria count water which IS very important and something a lot of 'beginner info' completely ignores. I also think his take on plants isnt necessarily correct, you can have a heavily planted heavily stocked tank but it has to be heavily filtered. People run into problems with underfiltered overstocked walstad aquariums but if you run them right it does work.

On the whole it's the type of site I would offer individual pages from but probably not provide as an overall general source. But I can appreciate that it's actually written by a real person with experience in the hobby and not by a pajeet with a bot trying to make clickbux or someone just parroting those garbage bot articles for reddit gold.

As for the food I think he does say somewhere that you should look for something with whole fish/fish meal as a top ingredient and high protein which I agree with. He then goes on a huge tangent that gets into the weeds, contains info of mixed quality and is irrelevant to most folks who would be seeking advice in the sticky.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4376692
Corey mostly uses sponges but has used undergravels and says they're good. IIRC I remember him saying the main reason he doesn't sell them is the old style hard/fixed plate ones are better than the snap together grate style but the boxes are big and expensive to ship, and they're also relatively fragile and likely to crack or break in shipping. I would think the other reason is he mostly caters to the easy/broad appeal stuff and undergravels are more of a bear to deal with if you fuck up. If you fuck up a sponge (somehow, i guess it might be possible) you can replace it easily. If you break an undergravel somehow, or clog it you're taking the entire tank apart to fix it.

IMO they are good, but to each their own. All filters are different variants of the same shit, run water over media. I think their main advantage is they have more media/surface area, are less likely to clog up (at reasonable stocking levels, feeding low-carb food) and are less ugly/obtrusive than a sponge is while still being in-tank which reduces the complexity of a system and risk of leaks.

I was watching some vendors this summer and one of the surprising sellers was zebra laces, they sell really well as long as they have good red eyes on your strain. Come to think of it I would say any black variation that has good red eyes will sell.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4378359
Sponges are great if they perfectly fit the volume (so water doesn't mostly "least resistance" around the outside of it), but definitely take maintenance to prevent clogging up and being useless. Replace with k1 micro or similar types of media for best, lowest effort results - biohome and other similar "high tech" crushed-glass doesn't really work, as the tiny holes get clogged almost immediately and then you just have the very limited outside surface area, which ends up worse than just using small gravel as media.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4378362
Ammonia spikes are a sign of inadequate filtration for sure, a cycled aquarium with enough filtration should pretty much never have measurable ammonia or nitrite.

A canister is going to be your best bet, but a big air-powered moving bed filter would be a cheap, effective stop-gap if you already have an air pump. If you have any space in your current filter, you can cut 1cm lengths of plastic drinking straws and fill up all water-touching available space with those bits, it'll improve the filtration until you get a canister. They're not as good as k1 or variants, but it's a cheap alternative - plastic dish scrubbing pads also work but will clog much easier.

It might be cheaper to find and create a sump, rather than a canister filter, if you can find a cheap 5g to 20g tank on local marketplace. It'll require some plumbing, but will cost way less and provide a better filter in the end, not sure how handy you are.

Worst case, throw some more floaters in there, and cut down to half current feeding schedule, while you wait for a canister. Azolla is probably the best nitrate removal but any fast growing one like duckweed or various salvinia will do help, and the ones with longer roots look nicer imo.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4378530
Wasn't shitting on sponges, they're just higher effort to keep clean than k1. You're right about path of least resistance, which is why biohome and such clog and are basically solid balls almost immediately. Any media volume needs to fill the space well enough that water can't flow entirely around it, and the big holes in k1 (along with cut straws as mentioned as a cheapo form) allows more surface area than a clogged sponge or clogged crushed glass ball, while still leaving enough space for water (and more importantly various waste) to actually flow through and hit the bacteria.

Sponges are great, but cut blocks of sponge or sponge with too fine of pores or sponge with a gap around it inside the filter quickly loses its effectiveness. Personally I hate cleaning filters, but will admit a biweekly-cleaned 30ppm sponge perfectly fitted to the volume of the filter is probably better overall filtration that the same volume crammed with static k1 micro, it just means you have to clean it more often than basically never.

Ive read a bit about freshwater clams (they are quite interesting) and it seems like a bad idea to keep them, overall. They only live up to 6 months and are very fragile to parameter changes. This means that even if you manage to acclimatize them perfectly, there is a very good chance that they will die of old age soon after you add them to the tank. Couple this with the fact that clams can hide under the substrate and it is not always easy to tell if they are alive and you have a ticking ammonia bomb.

>>4378741
Mimes have changed a lot over the years, evolutionarily speaking. There's a lot of gaps in the fossil record but, from what we can tell, mimes used to look quite different and be much smaller. They managed to survive by out-growing their early predators and eventually take on their most notable traits, which are mimicry, unique movement patterns, and dazzle markings.

Despite it only catching attention these days rather than startling predators away, the modern mime still carries high-contrast markings left over from these time periods as its body form now mimics one of the most successful animals on the planet (us!), and humans do not see mimes as food. Mimes, however, see human food sources as valuable resources to tap and so have adapted to be quite good at interfacing with humans, though the results of individual mimes' attempts range from amusingly friendly to disturbing. A young mime must hone their craft correctly to learn which behaviors result in the best levels of social tolerance by humans so as to acquire food/shelter and protection from other, more aggressive creatures. They're at least as smart as humans in many ways, though verbal linguistic center of their brains isn't quite on-par with that of a human, resulting in a preference for copycat facial expressions and body language.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4369930
Theoretically, yes. You get a large mechanical advantage because running blades are basically big springs that absorb the impact energy from the leg striking the ground and release almost all of it again in the forward direction on the upstroke. The energy return of carbon fiber running blades is something like 98% as opposed to the mere 14% of a natural leg.

It's worth noting that these advantages don't really show up in short distance running because your top speed is mostly determined by your leg swing times, which don't change based on what prosthetics you're wearing. Running blades also have a big disadvantage to acceleration because they don't generate as much force on the ground as regular feet. However, once an amputee runner hits their top speed they get to maintain it almost for free (as long as they're on flat ground and running in a straight line) so they can theoretically keep up a pace for much longer than a regular human.

Theoretically you could also just give anyone longer blades to make them faster, but everyone's collectively decided that's a bad idea for some reason.

>>4369797
Quadrupedal running and Bipedal running have different mechanics that demand different kinds of legs.
As other anons have noted, Quadruped sprinters like gazelles have legs that work more like springs. The main muscular input to their run cycle actually comes from the undulation of their backs. Since the legs don’t assume that function and only need to function like springs to keep the run going, it’s more efficient to have them be as skinny and light as possible to reduce weight and drag.
Human sprinting obviously doesn’t work this way. Pretty much all the muscle force propelling us forward has to come from just our two legs, so they need to be swole as fuck.

In 2010, 19-year-old Sam, an avid rugby player, was drinking with Jimmy Galvin and several more of his Australian “mates” when a slug began crawling across Galvin’s concrete patio at his home in Sydney.

“We were sitting over here, having a bit of red wine appreciation night, trying to act as grown-ups. And then the conversation came up, ‘Should I eat it?’ ” recalled Galvin. “And then off Sam went and bang, that’s how it happened.”

After downing the slug, Sam became weak and complained of severe pain in his legs, according to “The Sunday Project.” Sam’s mother, Katie Ballard, told the news show that at first they worried he might have multiple sclerosis, which had afflicted her husband. But doctors said no, that wasn’t the cause.

Then Sam turned to his mother and told her he had eaten a slug, “And I went, ‘No, no one gets sick from that,’ ” Katie Ballard said. CNN has also reached out to Ballard.

Soon, however, doctors told them otherwise. Sam had developed rat lungworm disease from the infected slug.

Soon after the diagnosis, Sam fell into a coma, where he remained for 420 days, Ballard said in the Australian news report. He woke up paralyzed, unable to eat without a tube or move without intense effort. He required 24-hour care, seven days a week.

But the disease didn’t affect his mental faculties, his family and friends said.

“He’s in there, 100%,” Galvin told “The Sunday Project.” “I apologized to Sam about everything that happened that night in the backyard. And he just started bawling his eyes out. I know he’s there.”

“Sam passed away on Friday morning at Hornsby Hospital, not far from where he grew up, surrounded by 20 of those he most loved in the world,” she wrote.

“Katie tells me ‘the room was so full of love,’ ” Wilkinson said. “One of his friends there in the room continued, ‘He had his voice and he said “I love you” several times to Katie.’ “

What is the most intelligent animal on earth other than humans? Justify your answer with evidence, research if possible.

You SHOULD be able to solve this.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: I think either crows, dolphins or orangutans.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Bit of an egocentric question, really its “what animals are most humanlike?”
You can’t answer what creatures or even machines are most intelligent because it boils down to sapience, or having a “soul”, or ultimately what is most human. Since we can’t communicate with non-human creatures and there’s no observable life outside this planet, we’re in a fishbowl of the intellectual arena.
You can observe animals to see if they display intelligence, but that only proves those animals are most capable of being studied. Perhaps mushrooms have a vast neural network understanding of its habitat. Perhaps a specific jungle cat has total understanding of anatomy and layout of a jungle. Perhaps trees speak very slowly to each other over a course of hundreds of years. These aren’t things we can really observe or study without communication.
